findings.title: Unchecked Low Level Calls vulnerability
findings.explanation: Uses `.send()` to transfer Ether (msg.sender.send, nftAddress.send, cfoAddress.send) without checking the returned boolean result, leading to potential silent failures.

findings.title: Denial Of Service vulnerability
findings.explanation: In ClockAuctionBase._bid, the calls `seller.transfer(sellerProceeds)` and `msg.sender.transfer(bidExcess)` use `.transfer` which will revert if the recipient’s fallback function fails, allowing a malicious or buggy contract to block auction completion and refunds, resulting in a denial of service.

findings.title: Bad Randomness vulnerability
findings.explanation: The code uses keccak256 with blockhash and now/blockhash to derive randomness, which is predictable and miner-manipulable

findings.title: Front Running vulnerability
findings.explanation: Uses blockhash(block.number) and blockhash(block.number-1) to derive ‘random’ bHash which is fully predictable off‐chain, allowing an attacker to compute the outcome and front‐run a pending surprisePanda transaction to claim the rare panda first.

findings.title: Time Manipulation vulnerability
findings.explanation: Use of now (block.timestamp) in randomness computation with keccak256 allows miner to manipulate birth outcome

findings.title: Other vulnerability
findings.explanation: Insecure randomness: using keccak256(block.blockhash(block.number - 2), now) for gene mixing/abortion probability allows miner manipulation

vulnerability_location.description: Uses `.send()` to transfer Ether (msg.sender.send, nftAddress.send, cfoAddress.send) without checking the returned boolean result, leading to potential silent failures.

In ClockAuctionBase._bid, the calls `seller.transfer(sellerProceeds)` and `msg.sender.transfer(bidExcess)` use `.transfer` which will revert if the recipient’s fallback function fails, allowing a malicious or buggy contract to block auction completion and refunds, resulting in a denial of service.
The code uses keccak256 with blockhash and now/blockhash to derive randomness, which is predictable and miner-manipulable

Uses blockhash(block.number) and blockhash(block.number-1) to derive ‘random’ bHash which is fully predictable off‐chain, allowing an attacker to compute the outcome and front‐run a pending surprisePanda transaction to claim the rare panda first.
Use of now (block.timestamp) in randomness computation with keccak256 allows miner to manipulate birth outcome
Insecure randomness: using keccak256(block.blockhash(block.number - 2), now) for gene mixing/abortion probability allows miner manipulation
